an5.48:1.1.pli: “Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, alabbhanīyāni ṭhānāni samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ.
an5.48:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are five things that cannot be had by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

an5.48:1.3.pli: ‘Jarādhammaṃ mā jīrī’ti alabbhanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ.
an5.48:1.3.eng: That someone liable to old age should not grow old.

an5.48:1.4.pli: ‘Byādhidhammaṃ mā byādhīyī’ti …pe… ‘maraṇadhammaṃ mā mīyī’ti … ‘khayadhammaṃ mā khīyī’ti … ‘nassanadhammaṃ mā nassī’ti alabbhanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ.
an5.48:1.4.eng: That someone liable to sickness should not get sick. … That someone liable to death should not die. … That someone liable to ending should not end. … That someone liable to perishing should not perish. …

an5.48:2.1.eng: An unlearned ordinary person has someone liable to old age who grows old.

an5.48:2.2.pli: So jarādhamme jiṇṇe na iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an5.48:2.2.eng: But they don’t reflect on old age:

an5.48:2.3.pli: ‘na kho mayhevekassa jarādhammaṃ jīrati, atha kho yāvatā sattānaṃ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbesaṃ sattānaṃ jarādhammaṃ jīrati.
an5.48:2.3.eng: ‘It’s not just me who has someone liable to old age who grows old. For as long as sentient beings come and go, pass away and are reborn, they all have someone liable to old age who grows old.

an5.48:2.4.pli: Ahañceva kho pana jarādhamme jiṇṇe soceyyaṃ kilameyyaṃ parideveyyaṃ, urattāḷiṃ kandeyyaṃ, sammohaṃ āpajjeyyaṃ, bhattampi me nacchādeyya, kāyepi dubbaṇṇiyaṃ okkameyya, kammantāpi nappavatteyyuṃ, amittāpi attamanā assu, mittāpi dummanā assū’ti.
an5.48:2.4.eng: If I were to sorrow and wail and lament, beating my breast and falling into confusion, just because someone liable to old age grows old, I’d lose my appetite and my physical appearance would deteriorate. My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’

an5.48:2.5.pli: So jarādhamme jiṇṇe socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an5.48:2.5.eng: And so, when someone liable to old age grows old, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an5.48:2.7.pli: ‘assutavā puthujjano viddho savisena sokasallena attānaṃyeva paritāpeti’.
an5.48:2.7.eng: an unlearned ordinary person struck by sorrow’s poisoned arrow, who only mortifies themselves.

an5.48:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, assutavato puthujjanassa byādhidhammaṃ byādhīyati …pe… maraṇadhammaṃ mīyati … khayadhammaṃ khīyati … nassanadhammaṃ nassati.
an5.48:3.1.eng: Furthermore, an unlearned ordinary person has someone liable to sickness … death … ending … perishing.

an5.48:3.2.pli: So nassanadhamme naṭṭhe na iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an5.48:3.2.eng: But they don’t reflect on perishing:

an5.48:3.3.pli: ‘na kho mayhevekassa nassanadhammaṃ nassati, atha kho yāvatā sattānaṃ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbesaṃ sattānaṃ nassanadhammaṃ nassati.
an5.48:3.3.eng: ‘It’s not just me who has someone liable to perishing who perishes. For as long as sentient beings come and go, pass away and are reborn, they all have someone liable to perishing who perishes.

an5.48:3.4.pli: Ahañceva kho pana nassanadhamme naṭṭhe soceyyaṃ kilameyyaṃ parideveyyaṃ, urattāḷiṃ kandeyyaṃ, sammohaṃ āpajjeyyaṃ, bhattampi me nacchādeyya, kāyepi dubbaṇṇiyaṃ okkameyya, kammantāpi nappavatteyyuṃ, amittāpi attamanā assu, mittāpi dummanā assū’ti.
an5.48:3.4.eng: If I were to sorrow and wail and lament, beating my breast and falling into confusion, just because someone liable to perishing perishes, I’d lose my appetite and my physical appearance would deteriorate. My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’

an5.48:3.5.pli: So nassanadhamme naṭṭhe socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an5.48:3.5.eng: And so, when someone liable to perishing perishes, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an5.48:3.7.pli: ‘assutavā puthujjano viddho savisena sokasallena attānaṃyeva paritāpeti’.
an5.48:3.7.eng: an unlearned ordinary person struck by sorrow’s poisoned arrow, who only mortifies themselves.

an5.48:4.1.pli: Sutavato ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa jarādhammaṃ jīrati.
an5.48:4.1.eng: A learned noble disciple has someone liable to old age who grows old.

an5.48:4.2.eng: So they reflect on old age:

an5.48:4.3.pli: ‘na kho mayhevekassa jarādhammaṃ jīrati, atha kho yāvatā sattānaṃ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbesaṃ sattānaṃ jarādhammaṃ jīrati.
an5.48:4.3.eng: ‘It’s not just me who has someone liable to old age who grows old. For as long as sentient beings come and go, pass away and are reborn, they all have someone liable to old age who grows old.

an5.48:4.4.pli: Ahañceva kho pana jarādhamme jiṇṇe soceyyaṃ kilameyyaṃ parideveyyaṃ, urattāḷiṃ kandeyyaṃ, sammohaṃ āpajjeyyaṃ, bhattampi me nacchādeyya, kāyepi dubbaṇṇiyaṃ okkameyya, kammantāpi nappavatteyyuṃ, amittāpi attamanā assu, mittāpi dummanā assū’ti.
an5.48:4.4.eng: If I were to sorrow and wail and lament, beating my breast and falling into confusion, just because someone liable to old age grows old, I’d lose my appetite and my physical appearance would deteriorate. My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’

an5.48:4.5.pli: So jarādhamme jiṇṇe na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an5.48:4.5.eng: And so, when someone liable to old age grows old, they don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an5.48:4.7.pli: ‘sutavā ariyasāvako abbuhi savisaṃ sokasallaṃ, yena viddho assutavā puthujjano attānaṃyeva paritāpeti.
an5.48:4.7.eng: a learned noble disciple who has drawn out sorrow’s poisoned arrow, struck by which unlearned ordinary people only mortify themselves.

an5.48:4.8.eng: Sorrowless, free of thorns, that noble disciple only extinguishes themselves.

an5.48:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavato ariyasāvakassa byādhidhammaṃ byādhīyati …pe… maraṇadhammaṃ mīyati … khayadhammaṃ khīyati … nassanadhammaṃ nassati.
an5.48:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a learned noble disciple has someone liable to sickness … death … ending … perishing.

an5.48:5.3.pli: ‘na kho mayhevekassa nassanadhammaṃ nassati, atha kho yāvatā sattānaṃ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbesaṃ sattānaṃ nassanadhammaṃ nassati.
an5.48:5.3.eng: ‘It’s not just me who has someone liable to perishing who perishes. For as long as sentient beings come and go, pass away and are reborn, they all have someone liable to perishing who perishes.

an5.48:5.4.pli: Ahañceva kho pana nassanadhamme naṭṭhe soceyyaṃ kilameyyaṃ parideveyyaṃ, urattāḷiṃ kandeyyaṃ, sammohaṃ āpajjeyyaṃ, bhattampi me nacchādeyya, kāyepi dubbaṇṇiyaṃ okkameyya, kammantāpi nappavatteyyuṃ, amittāpi attamanā assu, mittāpi dummanā assū’ti.
an5.48:5.4.eng: If I were to sorrow and wail and lament, beating my breast and falling into confusion, just because someone liable to perishing perishes, I’d lose my appetite and my physical appearance would deteriorate. My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’

an5.48:5.5.pli: So nassanadhamme naṭṭhe na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an5.48:5.5.eng: And so, when someone liable to perishing perishes, they don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an5.48:5.7.pli: ‘sutavā ariyasāvako abbuhi savisaṃ sokasallaṃ, yena viddho assutavā puthujjano attānaṃyeva paritāpeti.
an5.48:5.7.eng: a learned noble disciple who has drawn out sorrow’s poisoned arrow, struck by which unlearned ordinary people only mortify themselves.

an5.48:5.8.eng: Sorrowless, free of thorns, that noble disciple only extinguishes themselves.

an5.48:6.1.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañca alabbhanīyāni ṭhānāni samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasminti.
an5.48:6.1.eng: These are the five things that cannot be had by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

an5.48:7.2.eng: doesn’t do even a little bit of good.

an5.48:7.3.eng: When they know that you’re sad,

an5.48:8.1.eng: When an astute person doesn’t waver <j>in the face of adversity,

an5.48:8.2.eng: as they’re able to evaluate what’s beneficial,

an5.48:8.4.eng: seeing that their normal expression doesn’t change.

an5.48:9.3.eng: if by means of any such things you benefit,

an5.48:9.4.eng: then by all means keep doing them.

an5.48:10.1.eng: But if you understand that ‘this good thing

an5.48:10.2.eng: can’t be had by me or by anyone else’,

an5.48:10.3.eng: you should accept it without sorrowing, thinking:

an5.48:10.4.eng: ‘The deed is powerful. What can I do now?’”

an5.49:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an5.49:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an5.49:1.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
an5.49:1.2.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

an5.49:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena mallikā devī kālaṅkatā hoti.

an5.49:2.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro puriso yena rājā pasenadi kosalo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rañño pasenadissa kosalassa upakaṇṇake āroceti:
an5.49:2.2.eng: Then a man went up to the king and whispered in his ear,

an5.49:2.3.eng: “Your Majesty, Queen Mallikā has passed away.”

an5.49:2.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, rājā pasenadi kosalo dukkhī dummano pattakkhandho adhomukho pajjhāyanto appaṭibhāno nisīdi.
an5.49:2.4.eng: When this was said, King Pasenadi was miserable and sad. He sat with his shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.

an5.49:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ dukkhiṃ dummanaṃ pattakkhandhaṃ adhomukhaṃ pajjhāyantaṃ appaṭibhānaṃ viditvā rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ etadavoca:
an5.49:3.1.eng: Knowing this, the Buddha said to him,

an5.49:3.2.pli: “pañcimāni, mahārāja, alabbhanīyāni ṭhānāni samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ.
an5.49:3.2.eng: “Great king, there are five things that cannot be had by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

an5.49:3.4.pli: ‘Jarādhammaṃ mā jīrī’ti alabbhanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ …pe… na socanāya paridevanāya …pe… kammaṃ daḷhaṃ kinti karomi dānī”ti.
an5.49:3.4.eng: That someone liable to old age should not grow old. … Sorrowing and lamenting doesn’t do even a little bit of good … ‘The deed is powerful. What can I do now?’”

an5.5:1.1.pli: “Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati, tassa diṭṭheva dhamme pañca sahadhammikā vādānupātā gārayhā ṭhānā āgacchanti.
an5.5:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, any monk or nun who disavows the training and returns to a lesser life deserves rebuttal and criticism on five legitimate grounds in this very life.

an5.5:1.3.pli: Saddhāpi nāma te nāhosi kusalesu dhammesu, hirīpi nāma te nāhosi kusalesu dhammesu, ottappampi nāma te nāhosi kusalesu dhammesu, vīriyampi nāma te nāhosi kusalesu dhammesu, paññāpi nāma te nāhosi kusalesu dhammesu.
an5.5:1.3.eng: ‘You had no faith, conscience, prudence, energy, or wisdom regarding skillful qualities.’

an5.5:1.4.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati, tassa diṭṭheva dhamme ime pañca sahadhammikā vādānupātā gārayhā ṭhānā āgacchanti.
an5.5:1.4.eng: Any monk or nun who disavows the training and returns to a lesser life deserves rebuttal and criticism on these five legitimate grounds in this very life.

an5.5:2.1.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena assumukho rudamāno paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, tassa diṭṭheva dhamme pañca sahadhammikā pāsaṃsā ṭhānā āgacchanti.
an5.5:2.1.eng: Any monk or nun who lives the full and pure spiritual life in pain and sadness, weeping, with tearful face, deserves praise on five legitimate grounds in this very life.

an5.5:2.3.pli: Saddhāpi nāma te ahosi kusalesu dhammesu, hirīpi nāma te ahosi kusalesu dhammesu, ottappampi nāma te ahosi kusalesu dhammesu, vīriyampi nāma te ahosi kusalesu dhammesu, paññāpi nāma te ahosi kusalesu dhammesu.
an5.5:2.3.eng: ‘You had faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom regarding skillful qualities.’

an5.5:2.4.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena assumukho rudamāno paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, tassa diṭṭheva dhamme ime pañca sahadhammikā pāsaṃsā ṭhānā āgacchantī”ti.
an5.5:2.4.eng: Any monk or nun who lives the full and pure spiritual life in pain and sadness, weeping, with tearful face, deserves praise on these five legitimate grounds in this very life.”

an5.50:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā nārado pāṭaliputte viharati kukkuṭārāme.
an5.50:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Nārada was staying near Pāṭaliputta, in the Chicken Monastery.

an5.50:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena muṇḍassa rañño bhaddā devī kālaṅkatā hoti piyā manāpā.
an5.50:1.2.eng: Now at that time King Muṇḍa’s dear and beloved Queen Bhaddā had just passed away.

an5.50:1.3.pli: So bhaddāya deviyā kālaṅkatāya piyāya manāpāya neva nhāyati na vilimpati na bhattaṃ bhuñjati na kammantaṃ payojeti—
an5.50:1.3.eng: And since that time, the king did not bathe, anoint himself, eat his meals, or apply himself to his work.

an5.50:1.4.eng: Day and night he brooded over Queen Bhaddā’s corpse.

an5.50:1.5.pli: Atha kho muṇḍo rājā piyakaṃ kosārakkhaṃ āmantesi:
an5.50:1.5.eng: Then King Muṇḍa addressed Piyaka, the keeper of the treasury,

an5.50:1.6.pli: “tena hi, samma piyaka, bhaddāya deviyā sarīraṃ āyasāya teladoṇiyā pakkhipitvā aññissā āyasāya doṇiyā paṭikujjatha, yathā mayaṃ bhaddāya deviyā sarīraṃ cirataraṃ passeyyāmā”ti.
an5.50:1.6.eng: “So, my good Piyaka, please place Queen Bhaddā’s corpse in an iron casket filled with oil. Then close it up with another casket, so that we can view Queen Bhaddā’s body even longer.”

an5.50:1.7.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho piyako kosārakkho muṇḍassa rañño paṭissutvā bhaddāya deviyā sarīraṃ āyasāya teladoṇiyā pakkhipitvā aññissā āyasāya doṇiyā paṭikujji.
an5.50:1.7.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Piyaka, and he did as the king instructed.

an5.50:2.2.pli: “imassa kho muṇḍassa rañño bhaddā devī kālaṅkatā piyā manāpā.
an5.50:2.2.eng: “King Muṇḍa’s dear and beloved Queen Bhaddā has passed away.

an5.50:2.3.pli: So bhaddāya deviyā kālaṅkatāya piyāya manāpāya neva nhāyati na vilimpati na bhattaṃ bhuñjati na kammantaṃ payojeti—
an5.50:2.3.eng: Since then the king does not bathe, anoint himself, eat his meals, or apply himself to his work.

an5.50:2.4.eng: Day and night he broods over Queen Bhaddā’s corpse.

an5.50:2.5.pli: Kaṃ nu kho muṇḍo rājā samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā payirupāseyya, yassa dhammaṃ sutvā sokasallaṃ pajaheyyā”ti.
an5.50:2.5.eng: Now, what ascetic or brahmin might the king pay homage to, whose teaching could help the king give up sorrow’s arrow?”

an5.50:3.2.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā nārado pāṭaliputte viharati kukkuṭārāme.
an5.50:3.2.eng: “This Venerable Nārada is staying in the Chicken Monastery at Pāṭaliputta.

an5.50:3.3.pli: Taṃ kho panāyasmantaṃ nāradaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

an5.50:3.4.pli: ‘paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī bahussuto cittakathī kalyāṇapaṭibhāno vuddho ceva arahā ca’.
an5.50:3.4.eng: ‘He is astute, competent, intelligent, learned, a brilliant speaker, eloquent, mature, a perfected one.’

an5.50:3.5.pli: Yannūna muṇḍo rājā āyasmantaṃ nāradaṃ payirupāseyya, appeva nāma muṇḍo rājā āyasmato nāradassa dhammaṃ sutvā sokasallaṃ pajaheyyā”ti.
an5.50:3.5.eng: What if King Muṇḍa was to pay homage to Venerable Nārada? Hopefully when he hears Nārada’s teaching, the king could give up sorrow’s arrow.”

an5.50:4.1.pli: Atha kho piyako kosārakkho yena muṇḍo rājā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā muṇḍaṃ rājānaṃ etadavoca:
an5.50:4.1.eng: Then Piyaka went to the king and said to him,

an5.50:4.2.pli: “ayaṃ kho, deva, āyasmā nārado pāṭaliputte viharati kukkuṭārāme.
an5.50:4.2.eng: “Sire, this Venerable Nārada is staying in the Chicken Monastery at Pāṭaliputta.

an5.50:4.3.pli: Taṃ kho panāyasmantaṃ nāradaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

an5.50:4.4.pli: ‘paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī bahussuto cittakathī kalyāṇapaṭibhāno vuddho ceva arahā ca’.
an5.50:4.4.eng: ‘He is astute, competent, intelligent, learned, a brilliant speaker, eloquent, mature, a perfected one.’

an5.50:4.5.pli: Yadi pana devo āyasmantaṃ nāradaṃ payirupāseyya, appeva nāma devo āyasmato nāradassa dhammaṃ sutvā sokasallaṃ pajaheyyā”ti.
an5.50:4.5.eng: What if Your Majesty was to pay homage to Venerable Nārada? Hopefully when you hear Nārada’s teaching, you could give up sorrow’s arrow.”

an5.50:4.6.pli: “Tena hi, samma piyaka, āyasmantaṃ nāradaṃ paṭivedehi.
an5.50:4.6.eng: “Well then, my good Piyaka, let Nārada know.

an5.50:4.7.pli: Kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ pubbe appaṭisaṃvidito upasaṅkamitabbaṃ maññeyyā”ti.
an5.50:4.7.eng: For how on earth could one such as I presume to visit an ascetic or brahmin in my realm without letting them know beforehand?”

an5.50:4.8.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho piyako kosārakkho muṇḍassa rañño paṭissutvā yenāyasmā nārado tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ nāradaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho piyako kosārakkho āyasmantaṃ nāradaṃ etadavoca:
an5.50:4.8.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Piyaka. He went to Nārada, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

an5.50:5.1.pli: “Imassa, bhante, muṇḍassa rañño bhaddā devī kālaṅkatā piyā manāpā.
an5.50:5.1.eng: “Sir, King Muṇḍa’s dear and beloved Queen Bhaddā has passed away.

an5.50:5.2.pli: So bhaddāya deviyā kālaṅkatāya piyāya manāpāya neva nhāyati na vilimpati na bhattaṃ bhuñjati na kammantaṃ payojeti—
an5.50:5.2.eng: And since she passed away, the king has not bathed, anointed himself, eaten his meals, or got his business done.

an5.50:5.3.eng: Day and night he broods over Queen Bhaddā’s corpse.

an5.50:5.4.pli: Sādhu, bhante, āyasmā nārado muṇḍassa rañño tathā dhammaṃ desetu yathā muṇḍo rājā āyasmato nāradassa dhammaṃ sutvā sokasallaṃ pajaheyyā”ti.
an5.50:5.4.eng: Sir, please teach the king so that, when he hears your teaching, he can give up sorrow’s arrow.”

an5.50:5.5.eng: “Please, Piyaka, let the king come when he likes.”

an5.50:6.1.pli: Atha kho piyako kosārakkho uṭṭhāyāsanā āyasmantaṃ nāradaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena muṇḍo rājā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā muṇḍaṃ rājānaṃ etadavoca:
an5.50:6.1.eng: Then Piyaka got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled Venerable Nārada, keeping him on his right, before going to the king and saying,

an5.50:6.2.eng: “Sire, the request for an audience with Venerable Nārada has been granted.

an5.50:6.3.eng: Please, Your Majesty, go at your convenience.”

an5.50:6.4.pli: “Tena hi, samma piyaka, bhadrāni bhadrāni yānāni yojāpehī”ti.
an5.50:6.4.eng: “Well then, my good Piyaka, harness the finest chariots.”

an5.50:6.5.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho piyako kosārakkho muṇḍassa rañño paṭissutvā bhadrāni bhadrāni yānāni yojāpetvā muṇḍaṃ rājānaṃ etadavoca:
an5.50:6.5.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Piyaka. He did so, then told the king:

an5.50:6.6.pli: “yuttāni kho te, deva, bhadrāni bhadrāni yānāni.

an5.50:6.7.eng: Please, Your Majesty, go at your convenience.”

an5.50:7.1.pli: Atha kho muṇḍo rājā bhadraṃ yānaṃ abhiruhitvā bhadrehi bhadrehi yānehi yena kukkuṭārāmo tena pāyāsi mahaccā rājānubhāvena āyasmantaṃ nāradaṃ dassanāya.
an5.50:7.1.eng: Then King Muṇḍa mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp to see Venerable Nārada at the Chicken Monastery.

an5.50:7.2.pli: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi yānena gantvā, yānā paccorohitvā pattikova ārāmaṃ pāvisi.
an5.50:7.2.eng: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and entered the monastery on foot.

an5.50:7.3.pli: Atha kho muṇḍo rājā yena āyasmā nārado tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ nāradaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho muṇḍaṃ rājānaṃ āyasmā nārado etadavoca:
an5.50:7.3.eng: Then the king went up to Nārada, bowed, and sat down to one side. Then Nārada said to him:

an5.50:8.1.pli: “Pañcimāni, mahārāja, alabbhanīyāni ṭhānāni samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ.
an5.50:8.1.eng: “Great king, there are five things that cannot be had by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

an5.50:8.3.pli: ‘Jarādhammaṃ mā jīrī’ti alabbhanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ.
an5.50:8.3.eng: That someone liable to old age should not grow old. …

an5.50:8.4.pli: ‘Byādhidhammaṃ mā byādhīyī’ti …pe… ‘maraṇadhammaṃ mā mīyī’ti … ‘khayadhammaṃ mā khīyī’ti … ‘nassanadhammaṃ mā nassī’ti alabbhanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ.
an5.50:8.4.eng: That someone liable to sickness should not get sick. … That someone liable to death should not die. … That someone liable to ending should not end. … That someone liable to perishing should not perish. …

an5.50:9.1.eng: An unlearned ordinary person has someone liable to old age who grows old.

an5.50:9.2.pli: So jarādhamme jiṇṇe na iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an5.50:9.2.eng: But they don’t reflect on old age:

an5.50:9.3.pli: ‘na kho mayhevekassa jarādhammaṃ jīrati, atha kho yāvatā sattānaṃ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbesaṃ sattānaṃ jarādhammaṃ jīrati.
an5.50:9.3.eng: ‘It’s not just me who has someone liable to old age who grows old. For all sentient beings have someone liable to old age who grows old, as long as sentient beings come and go, pass away and are reborn.

an5.50:9.4.pli: Ahañceva kho pana jarādhamme jiṇṇe soceyyaṃ kilameyyaṃ parideveyyaṃ, urattāḷiṃ kandeyyaṃ, sammohaṃ āpajjeyyaṃ, bhattampi me nacchādeyya, kāyepi dubbaṇṇiyaṃ okkameyya, kammantāpi nappavatteyyuṃ, amittāpi attamanā assu, mittāpi dummanā assū’ti.
an5.50:9.4.eng: If I were to sorrow and wail and lament, beating my breast and falling into confusion, just because someone liable to old age grows old, I’d lose my appetite and my physical appearance would deteriorate. My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’

an5.50:9.5.pli: So jarādhamme jiṇṇe socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an5.50:9.5.eng: And so, when someone liable to old age grows old, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an5.50:9.7.pli: ‘assutavā puthujjano viddho savisena sokasallena attānaṃyeva paritāpeti’.
an5.50:9.7.eng: an unlearned ordinary person struck by sorrow’s poisoned arrow, who only mortifies themselves.

an5.50:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, mahārāja, assutavato puthujjanassa byādhidhammaṃ byādhīyati …pe… maraṇadhammaṃ mīyati … khayadhammaṃ khīyati … nassanadhammaṃ nassati.
an5.50:10.1.eng: Furthermore, an unlearned ordinary person has someone liable to sickness … death … ending … perishing.

an5.50:10.2.pli: So nassanadhamme naṭṭhe na iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an5.50:10.2.eng: But they don’t reflect on perishing:

an5.50:10.3.pli: ‘na kho mayhevekassa nassanadhammaṃ nassati, atha kho yāvatā sattānaṃ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbesaṃ sattānaṃ nassanadhammaṃ nassati.
an5.50:10.3.eng: ‘It’s not just me who has someone liable to perishing who perishes. For all sentient beings have someone liable to perishing who perishes, as long as sentient beings come and go, pass away and are reborn.

an5.50:10.4.pli: Ahañceva kho pana nassanadhamme naṭṭhe soceyyaṃ kilameyyaṃ parideveyyaṃ, urattāḷiṃ kandeyyaṃ, sammohaṃ āpajjeyyaṃ, bhattampi me nacchādeyya, kāyepi dubbaṇṇiyaṃ okkameyya, kammantāpi nappavatteyyuṃ, amittāpi attamanā assu, mittāpi dummanā assū’ti.
an5.50:10.4.eng: If I were to sorrow and wail and lament, beating my breast and falling into confusion, just because someone liable to perishing perishes, I’d lose my appetite and my physical appearance would deteriorate. My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’

an5.50:10.5.pli: So nassanadhamme naṭṭhe socati kilamati paridevati, urattāḷiṃ kandati, sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an5.50:10.5.eng: And so, when someone liable to perishing perishes, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an5.50:10.7.pli: ‘assutavā puthujjano viddho savisena sokasallena attānaṃyeva paritāpeti’.
an5.50:10.7.eng: an unlearned ordinary person struck by sorrow’s poisoned arrow, who only mortifies themselves.

an5.50:11.1.pli: Sutavato ca kho, mahārāja, ariyasāvakassa jarādhammaṃ jīrati.
an5.50:11.1.eng: A learned noble disciple has someone liable to old age who grows old.

an5.50:11.2.eng: So they reflect on old age:

an5.50:11.3.pli: ‘na kho mayhevekassa jarādhammaṃ jīrati, atha kho yāvatā sattānaṃ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbesaṃ sattānaṃ jarādhammaṃ jīrati.
an5.50:11.3.eng: ‘It’s not just me who has someone liable to old age who grows old. For all sentient beings have someone liable to old age who grows old, as long as sentient beings come and go, pass away and are reborn.

an5.50:11.4.pli: Ahañceva kho pana jarādhamme jiṇṇe soceyyaṃ kilameyyaṃ parideveyyaṃ, urattāḷiṃ kandeyyaṃ, sammohaṃ āpajjeyyaṃ, bhattampi me nacchādeyya, kāyepi dubbaṇṇiyaṃ okkameyya, kammantāpi nappavatteyyuṃ, amittāpi attamanā assu, mittāpi dummanā assū’ti.
an5.50:11.4.eng: If I were to sorrow and wail and lament, beating my breast and falling into confusion, just because someone liable to old age grows old, I’d lose my appetite and my physical appearance would deteriorate. My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’

an5.50:11.5.pli: So jarādhamme jiṇṇe na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an5.50:11.5.eng: And so, when someone liable to old age grows old, they don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an5.50:11.7.pli: ‘sutavā ariyasāvako abbuhi savisaṃ sokasallaṃ, yena viddho assutavā puthujjano attānaṃyeva paritāpeti.
an5.50:11.7.eng: a learned noble disciple who has drawn out sorrow’s poisoned arrow, struck by which unlearned ordinary people only mortify themselves.

an5.50:11.8.eng: Sorrowless, free of thorns, that noble disciple only extinguishes themselves.

an5.50:12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, mahārāja, sutavato ariyasāvakassa byādhidhammaṃ byādhīyati …pe… maraṇadhammaṃ mīyati … khayadhammaṃ khīyati … nassanadhammaṃ nassati.
an5.50:12.1.eng: Furthermore, a learned noble disciple has someone liable to sickness … death … ending … perishing.

an5.50:12.3.pli: ‘na kho mayhevekassa nassanadhammaṃ nassati, atha kho yāvatā sattānaṃ āgati gati cuti upapatti sabbesaṃ sattānaṃ nassanadhammaṃ nassati.
an5.50:12.3.eng: ‘It’s not just me who has someone liable to perishing who perishes. For all sentient beings have someone liable to perishing who perishes, as long as sentient beings come and go, pass away and are reborn.

an5.50:12.4.pli: Ahañceva kho pana nassanadhamme naṭṭhe soceyyaṃ kilameyyaṃ parideveyyaṃ, urattāḷiṃ kandeyyaṃ, sammohaṃ āpajjeyyaṃ, bhattampi me nacchādeyya, kāyepi dubbaṇṇiyaṃ okkameyya, kammantāpi nappavatteyyuṃ, amittāpi attamanā assu, mittāpi dummanā assū’ti.
an5.50:12.4.eng: If I were to sorrow and wail and lament, beating my breast and falling into confusion, just because someone liable to perishing perishes, I’d lose my appetite and my physical appearance would deteriorate. My work wouldn’t get done, my enemies would be encouraged, and my friends would be dispirited.’

an5.50:12.5.pli: So nassanadhamme naṭṭhe na socati na kilamati na paridevati, na urattāḷiṃ kandati, na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
an5.50:12.5.eng: And so, when someone liable to perishing perishes, they don’t sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

an5.50:12.7.pli: ‘sutavā ariyasāvako abbuhi savisaṃ sokasallaṃ, yena viddho assutavā puthujjano attānaṃyeva paritāpeti.
an5.50:12.7.eng: a learned noble disciple who has drawn out sorrow’s poisoned arrow, struck by which unlearned ordinary people only mortify themselves.

an5.50:12.8.eng: Sorrowless, free of thorns, that noble disciple only extinguishes themselves.

an5.50:13.1.pli: Imāni kho, mahārāja, pañca alabbhanīyāni ṭhānāni samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasminti.
an5.50:13.1.eng: These are the five things that cannot be had by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

an5.50:14.2.eng: doesn’t do even a little bit of good.

an5.50:14.3.eng: When they know that you’re sad,

an5.50:15.1.eng: When an astute person doesn’t waver <j>in the face of adversity,

an5.50:15.2.eng: as they’re able to evaluate what’s beneficial,

an5.50:15.4.eng: seeing that their normal expression doesn’t change.

an5.50:16.3.eng: if by means of any such things you benefit,

an5.50:16.4.eng: then by all means keep doing them.

an5.50:17.1.eng: But if you understand that ‘this good thing

an5.50:17.2.eng: can’t be had by me or by anyone else’,

an5.50:17.3.eng: you should accept it without sorrowing, thinking:

an5.50:17.4.eng: ‘The deed is powerful. What can I do now?’”

an5.50:18.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, muṇḍo rājā āyasmantaṃ nāradaṃ etadavoca:
an5.50:18.1.eng: When he said this, King Muṇḍa said to Venerable Nārada,

an5.50:18.2.eng: “Sir, what is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”

an5.50:18.3.eng: “Great king, this exposition of the teaching is named ‘Pulling Out Sorrow’s Arrow’.”

an5.50:18.4.eng: “Indeed, sir, this is the pulling out of sorrow’s arrow!

an5.50:18.5.pli: Imañhi me, bhante, dhammapariyāyaṃ sutvā sokasallaṃ pahīnan”ti.
an5.50:18.5.eng: Hearing this exposition of the teaching, I’ve given up sorrow’s arrow.”

an5.50:19.1.pli: Atha kho muṇḍo rājā piyakaṃ kosārakkhaṃ āmantesi:
an5.50:19.1.eng: Then King Muṇḍa addressed Piyaka, the keeper of the treasury,

an5.50:19.2.pli: “tena hi, samma piyaka, bhaddāya deviyā sarīraṃ jhāpetha; thūpañcassā karotha.
an5.50:19.2.eng: “Well then, my good Piyaka, cremate Queen Bhaddā’s corpse and build a monument.

an5.50:19.3.pli: Ajjatagge dāni mayaṃ nhāyissāma ceva vilimpissāma bhattañca bhuñjissāma kammante ca payojessāmā”ti.
an5.50:19.3.eng: From this day forth, I will bathe, anoint myself, eat my meals, and apply myself to my work.”
